real_simple_stats package¶

real_simple_stats.descriptive_statistics.draw_frequency_table(values: List[str]) → Dict[str, int]¶

Generate a frequency table from a list of categorical or discrete values.

real_simple_stats.descriptive_statistics.five_number_summary(values: List[float]) → Dict[str, float]¶

Return the five-number summary: min, Q1, median, Q3, max.

real_simple_stats.descriptive_statistics.interquartile_range(values: List[float]) → float¶
real_simple_stats.descriptive_statistics.is_continuous(values: List[float]) → bool¶

Determine if a variable is continuous (contains non-integer values).

real_simple_stats.descriptive_statistics.is_discrete(values: List[float]) → bool¶

Determine if a variable is discrete (all values are integers).

real_simple_stats.descriptive_statistics.mean(values: List[float]) → float¶
real_simple_stats.descriptive_statistics.median(values: List[float]) → float¶
real_simple_stats.descriptive_statistics.sample_std_dev(values: List[float]) → float¶
real_simple_stats.descriptive_statistics.sample_variance(values: List[float]) → float¶
real_simple_stats.probability_utils.bayes_theorem(p_b_given_a: float, p_a: float, p_b: float) → float¶

Computes P(A|B) using Bayes’ Theorem.

real_simple_stats.probability_utils.combinations(n: int, k: int) → int¶

Returns number of combinations (n choose k).

real_simple_stats.probability_utils.conditional_probability(p_a_and_b: float, p_b: float) → float¶

Returns P(A|B) = P(A and B) / P(B)

real_simple_stats.probability_utils.expected_value(values: List[float], probabilities: List[float]) → float¶
real_simple_stats.probability_utils.fundamental_counting(outcomes: List[int]) → int¶

Multiplies choices across stages to get total outcomes.

real_simple_stats.probability_utils.general_addition_rule(p_a: float, p_b: float, p_a_and_b: float) → float¶

Returns P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)

real_simple_stats.probability_utils.joint_probability(p_a: float, p_b: float) → float¶

Returns the joint probability P(A and B) for independent events.

real_simple_stats.probability_utils.mutually_exclusive(p_a: float, p_b: float) → float¶

Returns P(A or B) for mutually exclusive events.

real_simple_stats.probability_utils.permutations(n: int, k: int) → int¶

Returns number of permutations of k items from n.

real_simple_stats.probability_utils.probability_distribution_table(values: List[int], probabilities: List[float]) → Dict[int, float]¶
real_simple_stats.probability_utils.probability_not(p: float) → float¶

Returns the probability of an event NOT happening.

real_simple_stats.probability_utils.probability_tree(branches: List[Tuple[float, float]]) → float¶

Calculates total probability of desired outcomes through tree branches.

Parameters:

branches – list of tuples (P(path1), P(subpath|path1))

Returns:

Total probability of reaching desired outcome.

real_simple_stats.hypothesis_testing.f_test(var1: float, var2: float) → float¶

Conduct F-test: variance1 / variance2

real_simple_stats.hypothesis_testing.is_right_tailed(test_statistic: float, critical_value: float) → bool¶
real_simple_stats.hypothesis_testing.is_two_tailed(test_statistic: float, critical_value: float) → bool¶
real_simple_stats.hypothesis_testing.p_value_method(test_statistic: float, test_type: str = 'two-tailed') → float¶

real_simple_stats.linear_regression_utils.coefficient_of_determination(x: List[float], y: List[float]) → float¶

Returns R^2, the coefficient of determination.

real_simple_stats.linear_regression_utils.linear_regression(x: List[float], y: List[float]) → Tuple[float, float, float, float, float]¶

Returns slope, intercept, r_value, p_value, std_err Formula: y = a + b*x

real_simple_stats.linear_regression_utils.manual_slope_intercept(x: List[float], y: List[float]) → Tuple[float, float]¶

Computes slope and intercept manually.

real_simple_stats.linear_regression_utils.pearson_correlation(x: List[float], y: List[float]) → float¶

Computes Pearson’s correlation coefficient (r).

real_simple_stats.linear_regression_utils.prepare_scatter_data(x: List[float], y: List[float]) → Tuple[List[float], List[float]]¶

Prepare data for plotting a scatter plot (returns as-is).

real_simple_stats.linear_regression_utils.regression_equation(x: float, slope: float, intercept: float) → float¶

Compute predicted y value using regression line.

real_simple_stats.normal_distributions.area_between_0_and_z(z: float) → float¶

Find area under normal curve between 0 and z (assumes standard normal).

real_simple_stats.normal_distributions.area_between_z_scores(z1: float, z2: float) → float¶

Area between two z-scores.

real_simple_stats.normal_distributions.area_in_tail(z: float) → float¶

Area to the right (or left) of a z-score.

real_simple_stats.normal_distributions.area_left_of_z(z: float) → float¶

Cumulative probability to the left of z.

real_simple_stats.normal_distributions.area_outside_range(z1: float, z2: float) → float¶

Area outside of range bounded by two z-scores (two-tailed).

real_simple_stats.normal_distributions.area_right_of_z(z: float) → float¶

Cumulative probability to the right of z.

real_simple_stats.normal_distributions.chebyshev_theorem(k: float) → float¶

Returns minimum proportion of values within k standard deviations of the mean.

real_simple_stats.normal_distributions.z_score(x: float, mean: float, std_dev: float) → float¶

Calculate the z-score for a single value.

real_simple_stats.normal_distributions.z_score_standard_error(sample_mean: float, population_mean: float, std_dev: float, sample_size: int) → float¶

Z-score using the standard error of the mean.

real_simple_stats.plots.plot_box(data, showfliers=False)¶

Plot a horizontal boxplot without outliers.

real_simple_stats.plots.plot_norm_hist(data, mean, std, bins=30, show_pdf=True, show_lines=True, title=True)¶

Plot a histogram of data with optional normal curve and markers.

real_simple_stats.plots.plot_observed_vs_expected(observed, expected, title='Observed vs Expected')¶

Minimalist bar plot comparing observed and expected frequencies.

Parameters:

  • observed – List of observed counts.

  • expected – List of expected counts.

  • title – Plot title.

real_simple_stats.plots.set_minimalist_style()¶

Apply a Tufte-inspired minimalist style to Matplotlib.

real_simple_stats.binomial_distributions.binomial_mean(n: int, p: float) → float¶
real_simple_stats.binomial_distributions.binomial_probability(n: int, k: int, p: float) → float¶

Computes probability of k successes in n binomial trials.

real_simple_stats.binomial_distributions.binomial_std_dev(n: int, p: float) → float¶
real_simple_stats.binomial_distributions.binomial_variance(n: int, p: float) → float¶
real_simple_stats.binomial_distributions.expected_value_multiple(values: List[float], probabilities: List[float]) → float¶
real_simple_stats.binomial_distributions.expected_value_single(value: float, probability: float) → float¶

Expected value of a single outcome.

real_simple_stats.binomial_distributions.is_binomial_experiment(trials: int, outcomes: List[str], probability: float) → bool¶

Checks if an experiment meets the binomial criteria: - fixed number of trials - each trial is independent - each trial has two possible outcomes - probability of success is constant

real_simple_stats.binomial_distributions.normal_approximation(n: int, p: float, k: int, use_continuity: bool = True) → float¶

Uses normal approximation with continuity correction to estimate binomial P(X ≤ k).

real_simple_stats.chi_square_utils.chi_square_statistic(observed: List[int], expected: List[int]) → float¶

Compute the chi-square statistic: Σ((O - E)^2 / E)

real_simple_stats.chi_square_utils.critical_chi_square_value(alpha: float, df: int) → float¶

Return the critical chi-square value (right-tailed only).

Parameters:

  • alpha – Significance level (e.g., 0.05)

  • df – Degrees of freedom

Returns:

Right-tailed critical value from the chi-square distribution.

real_simple_stats.chi_square_utils.reject_null_chi_square(chi_stat: float, critical_value: float) → bool¶

Determine whether to reject H0 based on test statistic and critical value.

Parameters:

  • chi_stat – The chi-square statistic.

  • critical_value – The critical value for the given alpha and df.

Returns:

True if the null hypothesis should be rejected.
